abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Disabilities
            Project for Iraq were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was substantial;
            Bank performance was moderately satisfactory and grantee
            performance was also moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons
            learned includes: Giving more time for a solid preparation
            work would save time in implementation. The project was
            designed to provide rehabilitation services as a matter of
            urgency. Speeding up the preparation process does not always
            allow for developing some project aspects in details.
            Project design needs to take into consideration the
            particular characteristics of the country, aiming not
            necessarily for the assumed best practice but for the best
            fit. An emergency project to provide disability assistance
            should not have a policy component. The bank should always
            assume low institutional capacity and high turnover in a
            conflict, post conflict, fragile situation.

            PROJECT (BANK-EXEC)

abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper concerns
            restructuring of the Iraq Emergency Disabilities Project,
            and any accompanying amendments to the project's legal
            documents. The changes in project scope and components are
            required due to the challenging political and security
            conditions in the country after project effectiveness. As a
            result of this context, implementation was significantly
            delayed, and the number of project sites was reduced. The
            restructuring will result in cancellation of US$2.7 million
            of the grant proceeds and reallocation of the remaining
            amount to the revised activities. This restructuring will
            require an extension of the project closing date to June 30,
            2010, as agreed with the Ministry of Health (MOH). The
            project development objective (PDO) has been revised, as
            follows: to improve access of the disabled population in the
            targeted areas in Iraq to rehabilitation and prosthetic
            services. This will be carried out by: (i) constructing new
            facilities and workshops and equipping them; (ii) upgrading
            technical skills of the service providers; and (iii)
            providing medical aids to the disabled persons. The
            restructured project is expected to result in: (a) an
            increase in the number of disabled using the newly
            constructed and equipped facilities, and (b) an increase in
            the number of disabled who will receive medical aids.

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objective of the Emergency
            Disabilities Project for Iraq is to support the delivery of
            improved rehabilitation and prosthetic services that reduce
            the burden of physical disability. There will be three
            project components:  1) policy development and partnerships
            (US$0.8 million total, including contingencies) to develop a
            comprehensive policy and legislative framework for
            disabilities, and to initiate an enabling environment for
            development of partnerships between the Ministry of Health,
            other ministries, and civil society; 2) delivery of services
            to disabled persons (US$18 million total, including
            contingencies) to improve the delivery of community-oriented
            rehabilitation and prosthetic services for disabled persons
            in selected sites throughout the country; and 3) project
            management (US$0.7 million total, including contingencies)
            to ensure effective administration and coordination of the
            project activities.

repnme.cdata!:
Iraq - Emergency Disabilities Project :
            environmental and social screening and assessment framework

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental and social screening
            and assessment framework for the Iraq Emergency Disabilities
            Project aims to ensure that activities under the proposed
            reconstruction operations will address the following issues:
            protect human health; prevent or compensate any loss of
            livelihood; minimize environmental degradation minimize
            impacts on cultural property; and enhance positive
            environmental and social outcomes. Potential adverse impacts
            would be mitigated as follows: To prevent disease caused by
            poor water quality/contamination, prioritize leak detection
            and repair pipe networks, test chemical and bacterial
            content of water content prior to installation of new
            sources and redesign if found to be contaminated, monitor
            sources, place apron and drainage around tubewells and dug
            wells to prevent formation of stagnant pools, provide cover
            and hand-pump to prevent contamination of dug wells, locate
            pit latrines more than 10m from any water source and seal
            and separate base by at least 2m of sand or loamy soil from
            the groundwater table, seal night soil latrines or septic
            tanks, and drain outflows either to a soak away located at
            least 10m from any water source or connect it to a working
            drain. To prevent water depletion, use water use planning
            and include community participation of downstream water
            users, establish user rights through focus groups, and use
            archeological chance find procedures when uncovering
            cultural property. To reduce disease caused by excreta
            disposal or improper latrine use, wear protective clothing
            and use containers for night soil transport, treat waste and
            store in sunlight for sufficient period to destroy
            pathogens, and provide health and hygiene education and
            awareness. Minimize health risks from insects, rats, waste
            burning , medical waste, and odors by frequent collection,
            waste containment, separation at source-especially for
            medical and hazardous waste, minimize burning, prevent
            illegal dumping, incorporate dumping bays for safe access
            for rag pickers, invest in final disposal site, and provide
            daily soil covering. To prevent drainage disruption, erosion
            loss of vegetation and of access fro road construction,
            provide cascades, steps, and check dams; balance cut and
            fill, revegetate, restore borrow areas, construct in the dry
            season, protect soil surfaces, use turfing and create slope
            breaks, provide alternate road alignments, provide fuel to
            prevent firewood use, and properly dispose of oil and
            bitumen. To reduce deforestation, injury from earthquake,
            and injury from dam failure, use fired bricks, apply
            low-cost seismic structural designs, apply dam safety
            measures, and use watering and compaction for earthen dams.
            To offset impacts associated with power generation, use
            cleanest fuel economically available, contain spills, use
            sound-proofing, and store coolant oil in sealed containers,
            make population aware of electrocution dangers.
